Arjun Chandra wrote:

>(apologies, off-topic again)
>
>That coursemate would be *ME*. Xin Yao is a great speaker and a 
>highly motivating and encouraging supervisor as well and yes it sure 
>is very hard to catch him. I am currently writing a paper with him 
>which of course deals with the group's favourite topic - 
>neuroevolution, but from an ensemble learning perspective. 
>
>I'll second to Kennon's view on this MSc programme. It indeed is 
>intellectually stimulating.
>
>cheers,
>Arjun
>  
>
Hi Kennon, Arjun,

Entirely coincental but I happen to be from Birmingham - or nearby now 
anyhow. Yeh, I was aware that there is an AI group there (Natural 
Computation is a much nicer term), though I've never had any contact 
with anyone in the group -  it does seem to have developed quite a bit 
since I last checked it out. Xin Yao's 1999 paper "Evolving Artificial 
Neural Networks" was really the catalyst for me to have a go at an EANN 
project instead of just thinking about it. Currently that means 
developing my own version of NEAT in C# which I'm keen to try against a 
range of domains to get a feel for myself  just what NEAT (and similar 
techniques) are capable of and what their limits are.

Anyway it's interesting you guys are on this list. Are you or are any of 
your colleagues actually working with NEAT? or are you just lurking? :)

Perhaps I'll catch you off list since this is potentially straying 
off-topic somewhat.

Colin.
